verses.text: The divisions of the descendants of Aaron were as follows. Aaron’s sons were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
verses.comment: Aaron, the first high priest, had four sons, who become central to the priestly lineage. See also Exodus 6:23 for the genealogy detail.

verses.text: But Nadab and Abihu died before their father and had no sons. So Eleazar and Ithamar served as priests.
verses.comment: Nadab and Abihu's tragic death (Lev. 10:1-2) solidifies the priesthood through Eleazar and Ithamar. Note the importance of lineage and obedience.

verses.text: With the help of Zadok from Eleazar’s descendants and Ahimelech from Ithamar’s, David divided their duties for the service in God’s house.
verses.comment: David, under divine guidance, establishes priestly order, prefiguring the orderly structure of spiritual authority. Zadok and Ahimelech represent continuity and legitimacy in the priesthood.

verses.text: There were more leaders from Eleazar’s descendants than Ithamar’s. They were divided accordingly: sixteen heads from Eleazar’s families, and eight from Ithamar’s.
verses.comment: Eleazar's larger representation signals both grace and responsibility in the priestly role, as continued through generations.

verses.text: They divided them by lot, for there were officers of the sanctuary and officers of God among both Eleazar’s and Ithamar’s families.
verses.comment: Casting lots was a way to discern God’s will without human partiality, reflecting deep trust in divine providence (see Acts 1:26).

verses.text: Shemaiah son of Nethanel, the scribe, from the Levites, recorded them in the presence of the king, the leaders, Zadok the priest, Ahimelech son of Abiathar, and the family heads of the priests and the Levites—one family taken from Eleazar, then one from Ithamar, by turn.
verses.comment: The meticulous record-keeping highlights the importance of tradition and continuity, which safeguard orthodoxy and order in worship.

verses.text: The first lot fell to Jehoiarib, the second to Jedaiah,
verses.comment: Beginning the priestly courses, Jehoiarib and Jedaiah’s names reappear in later records (see Neh. 12:6, 7), showing succession and memory in God’s plan.

verses.text: the third to Harim, the fourth to Seorim,
verses.comment: The specific listing of priestly lots embodies the value of spiritual order, as seen in Temple and Church life.

verses.text: the fifth to Malchijah, the sixth to Mijamin,
verses.comment: Malchijah and Mijamin appear in post-exilic lists, showing continuity and restoration after exile—a prophetic shadow of spiritual restoration.

verses.text: the seventh to Hakkoz, the eighth to Abijah,
verses.comment: Abijah’s division is significant; Zechariah, the father of John the Baptist, served in this course (Luke 1:5), foreshadowing the coming of Christ through priestly service.

verses.text: the ninth to Jeshua, the tenth to Shecaniah,
verses.comment: The priestly succession continues, preserving worship and teaching.

verses.text: the eleventh to Eliashib, the twelfth to Jakim,
verses.comment: Priestly heads often reappear in leadership roles after the exile, linking the faith of the fathers to generations yet to come.

verses.text: the thirteenth to Huppah, the fourteenth to Jeshebeab,
verses.comment: The numbered divisions symbolize order and the unity of worship carried throughout the nation.

verses.text: the fifteenth to Bilgah, the sixteenth to Immer,
verses.comment: Immer’s descendants were notable post-exilic leaders, showing God’s faithfulness to priestly families.

verses.text: the seventeenth to Hezir, the eighteenth to Happizzez,
verses.comment: These names highlight ancient faithfulness, remembered through their inclusion in the sacred order.

verses.text: the nineteenth to Pethahiah, the twentieth to Jehezkel,
verses.comment: Every priestly division mattered greatly in preserving the spiritual heritage of Israel, showing God's attention to every detail.

verses.text: the twenty-first to Jachin, the twenty-second to Gamul,
verses.comment: Gamul’s name connects with others listed among priestly elders, emphasizing continuity.

verses.text: the twenty-third to Delaiah, and the twenty-fourth to Maaziah.
verses.comment: Twenty-four divisions provided priestly service for each week of the year, a sign of the perpetual offering and ministry before God (see Rev. 4:4 for symbolism of twenty-four elders).

verses.text: These were their appointed duties for serving in the LORD’s house according to the regulations given to them by Aaron their ancestor, as the LORD God of Israel had commanded him.
verses.comment: Obedience to divine ordinance and the transmission from Aaron to his sons emphasizes the sacredness of worship passed on through tradition and authority.

verses.text: From the rest of Levi’s sons: from Amram’s sons, Shubael; from Shubael’s sons, Jehdeiah;
verses.comment: The Levites, as the tribe set apart for service, remind us of a wider spiritual priesthood, serving alongside the sons of Aaron.

verses.text: From Rehabiah: from Rehabiah’s sons, Isshiah, the chief;
verses.comment: Isshiah is specifically set as the leader among Rehabiah’s descendants, ensuring clear lines of leadership.

verses.text: From the Izharites: Shelomoth; from Shelomoth’s sons, Jahath;
verses.comment: The Izharites are another important Levitical family, forming part of the complex structure of worship.

verses.text: From Hebron's sons: Jeriah, Amariah the second, Jahaziel the third, Jekameam the fourth.
verses.comment: The detailed listing of Hebron's sons reflects the faithfulness of recording and transmitting spiritual heritage.

verses.text: From Uzziel’s sons: Micah; from Micah’s sons, Shamir;
verses.comment: Lineages are preserved with precision, which strengthens collective memory and identity for spiritual leadership.

verses.text: Micah’s brother was Isshiah. From Isshiah’s sons: Zechariah.
verses.comment: Familial ties highlight the continuity of service, crucial for maintaining unity and succession.

verses.text: The Merarites: Mahli and Mushi—sons of Jaaziah.
verses.comment: The Merarite clan rounds out the Levitical tribes, all of whom share in the work set apart for God’s house.

verses.text: The sons of Jaaziah: Beno, Shoham, Zaccur, and Ibri.
verses.comment: Listing Jaaziah’s sons completes the full accounting of Merarite family heads.

verses.text: From Mahli: Eleazar, who had no sons.
verses.comment: The absence of heirs from Eleazar notes the importance of succession and continuity for ministry.

verses.text: From Kish: Kish’s son, Jerahmeel.
verses.comment: Even when lines seem minor, their role in worship and in God's plan is underscored by meticulous inclusion.

verses.text: The sons of Mushi: Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth. These were the Levites according to their families.
verses.comment: The Levitical families are listed with great care, underlining the communal and generational nature of ministry.

verses.text: These also cast lots, just as their relatives the descendants of Aaron did, in the presence of King David, Zadok, Ahimelech, and the family heads of the priests and the Levites—the families both chief and youngest alike.
verses.comment: The casting of lots by all families—including the youngest—shows the impartiality and unity intended for worship. The structure and transmission of spiritual authority is seen here as divinely ordered, foreshadowing the enduring role of a unified spiritual leadership in God’s plan.
